Mahmoudi et al., 2011; DeSantis et al., 2014). As a result, the outcome of chemotherapy is often 35 limited by safe dosage, generating insufficient drug concentration in tumor site. Moreover, drug 36 resistance is possibly developed to further hamper the overall efficacy during the treatment course 37 (Holohan et al., 2013). Thus, it is urgent to improve specific delivery to reduce side effects, and 38 optimize the therapeutic efficacy at a lower tolerance dose. 39
Hyperthermia as cancer therapy refers to the treatment of cancer through heating and has been used 40 in various forms since the original study pioneered by Coley in the end of 19th century (Mallory et 41 al., 2016). Although it can be used alone, hyperthermia is most often used in combination with other 42 therapeutic modalities including chemotherapy and radiation therapy. Hyperthermia typically falls 43 under three categories: local hyperthermia, regional hyperthermia, and whole-body hyperthermia. 44 Clinical application of heat can be induced by radiofrequency, microwave, ultrasound, or perfusion 45 methods (Falk and Issels, 2001). While these methods heat tissues efficiently, they also cause either a 46 risk of systemic toxicity from whole-body hyperthermia exposure, require invasive surgery or probe, 47 or may damage normal tissues due to non-targeted heating in local region (Wust et al., 2002). Thus, 48 photothermal therapy has been proposed as a promising modality for hyperthermia treatment. 49 Compared with other methods, light is an ideal external stimulus as it is easily regulated, focused, 50 and remotely controlled. The ease of control and focus enables better targeted treatments and leads to 51 less damage in healthy tissues. 52
NIR photothermal therapy as an emerging strategy, utilizing NIR laser-generated heat to conduct 53 cancer treatment, has gained increasing attentions (Peng et al., 2011; Wu et al., 2013; Yue et al., 54 2013). In NIR window, NIR light is minimally absorbed by endogenous absorbers in tissues, which 55 offers deeper tissue penetration in vivo (Weissleder, 2001; Weissleder and Ntziachristos, 2003). 56 Besides the heat ablation for direct cell killing in tumor, NIR light-induced mild hyperthermia can 57 increase vascular permeability in tumor tissues with newly formed immature blood vessels, which 58 brings specific drug accumulation and enhanced cytotoxicity (Hauck et al., 2008; Park et al., 2009). 59 Various kinds of nano-structured materials, including both organic and inorganic nanomaterials, have 60 been designed and applied for photothermal therapy as shown in several excellent reviews (Jung et 61 al., 2018; Khafaji et al., 2019; Vines et al., 2019). However, due to the non-uniform heat distribution 62 and restricted laser power to avoid normal tissue damage, the photothermal therapy alone is unlikely 63 to eradicate tumor completely (Wang et al., 2013b; Luo et al., 2017). 64
To address these issues, nanomaterials-based combination of chemotherapy and hyperthermia has 65 exhibited the effectiveness in optimizing the efficacy for cancer treatment (You et al., 2012; Zheng et 66 al., 2013; Wang et al., 2014a). It is well known that nanomedicines can preferentially accumulate in 67 tumor site through passive targeting via enhanced permeability and retention (EPR) effect, or active 68 targeting via surface-conjugated molecules (Jain and Stylianopoulos, 2010; Kratz and Warnecke, 69 2012). Their unique physicochemical properties also offer different pharmacokinetics and in vivo 70 distribution for loaded chemotherapeutic agents (Ernsting et al., 2013). In another hand, 71 nanomaterials-mediated NIR photothermal therapy is finely localized inside the tumor region, and the 72 hyperthermia is tunable simply by controlling the timing and intensity of the extrinsic energy source 73 (Kim et al., 2016). It has been widely accepted that combined chemo-photothermal therapy based on 74 nanomaterials exhibits remarkable advantages over single cancer treatment. Generally, co-delivery of 75 cytotoxic drugs and hyperthermia can simultaneously exert two benefits to improve cancer treatments, 76 and combined chemo-photothermal therapy usually generates synergistic effect. Photothermal 77 ablation coupled with targeted drug delivery can synergistically enhance therapeutic index via 78 different manner: (i) elevating cell membrane permeability; (ii) augmenting drug cytotoxicity (Hahn 79 et al., 1975; Overgaard, 1976); (iii) triggering drug release at target region. So far, there 81 have been several related reviews published, reporting either organic or inorganic nanomaterials for 82 chemo-photothermal combination therapy (Zhang et al., 2013; Zhang et al., 2018a; Khafaji et al., 83 2019). Considering the rapid development of this research area, we believe it is highly desirable and 84 important to systematically summarize the recent advances in combined chemo-photothermal therapy 85 based on both organic and inorganic nanomaterials. 86
Herein, we will review the recent efforts to design and construct nanomaterials for cancer chemo-87 photothermal therapy. This topic will be presented based on the properties and classifications of 88 nanomaterials applied as photothermal agents and nanocarriers. Upon briefly elaborating new 89 progress in metal and carbon nanomaterials mediated chemo-photothermal therapy, organic 90 nanomaterials-based combination therapy was discussed in particular. Material design and 91 formulations for integrated drug delivery and NIR-responsive hyperthermia are highlighted on the 92 background of their potential capacity in optimizing efficacy of cancer treatment. 93

3 Metal nanomaterials-based chemo-photothermal therapy 96
3.1 Gold nanoparticles 97
As is well known, gold nanoparticles (AuNPs) have been widely investigated in biomedical fields 98 due to their unique size- and shape-dependent optical and photothermal properties, originating from 99 localized surface plasmon resonance (LSPR) where collective oscillation of electrons occurs on the 100 surface of AuNPs after light absorption at a certain frequency (Cobley et al., 2011; Dreaden et al., 101 2012; Saha et al., 2012). Following excitation of LSPR by NIR laser, the attenuation of resonance 102 energy can occur through radiative and nonradiative relaxation, generating localized heat to 103 surrounding medium. The heat converted from absorbed NIR light can be used to perform 104 hyperthermia or trigger drug release in delivery systems (Hu et al., 2006; Dykman and Khlebtsov, 105 2012; Llevot and Astruc, 2012). AuNPs also exhibit chemical inertness and good biocompatibility in 106 biological tissues (Khlebtsov and Dykman, 2011). All these properties make AuNPs a promising 107 candidate for effective chemo-photothermal combination therapy (Figure 1). The synthesis of AuNPs 108 with controlled size and morphology has obtained various nanostructures such as gold nanorods 109 (Xiao et al., 2012; Ren et al., 2013; Shen et al., 2013; Manivasagan et al., 2019), gold nanoshells 110 (Lee et al., 2010; Liu et al., 2011), hollow gold nanospheres (You et al., 2010; You et al., 2012), gold 111 nanocages (Yavuz et al., 2009; Shi et al., 2012; Feng et al., 2019), and gold nanostar (Li et al., 2016b; 112 Zhang et al., 2016a), whose LSPR absorption features can be finely tuned to NIR region. However, 113 weak interactions between anticancer drugs and naked Au surface make them hardly attach to AuNPs 114 for in vitro or in vivo co-delivery application. Thus, extra outer/inner layer for molecule absorption or 115 pore-blocking strategy have been widely developed to load drug molecules for chemo-photothermal 116 therapy. For example, thermo-sensitive amphiphilic block polymer, lipoic acid conjugated 117 poly(ethylene glycol)-b-poly(ε-caprolactone), was employed to coat AuNRs surface for DOX loading 118 via hydrophobic interactions. Light-triggered drug release after NIR irradiation was achieved due to 119 the phase transition of poly(ε-caprolactone) on the AuNRs surface (Zhong et al., 2013). Mesoporous 120 silica has also been widely explored to decorate AuNPs for drug delivery. High surface area, tunable 121 pore size, and good biocompatibility make them suitable to augment drug loading capacity. For 122 instance, mesoporous silica-coated AuNRs were developed to encapsulate DOX for chemo-123 photothermal therapy, exhibiting light-controlled drug release under low-intensity NIR laser 124 Provi s on l

DNA duplex strands, consisting of sequential CG 126 base pairs, provide DOX loading sites on the AuNRs surface. Photothermal effects trigger de-127 hybridization of double-strand DNA by raising temperature higher than melting temperature to 128 release DOX under light-controlled mode (Xiao et al., 2012). Hollow gold nanospheres and gold 129 nanocages themselves could be employed as nano-carriers to load drugs into both outer and inner 130 space. A well-known AuNC-based system was fabricated by coating AuNC surface with thermo-131 sensitive polymer [poly-(N-isopropylacrylamide), pNIPAAm] as pore blockers. Following 132 temperature rise above a certain threshold, pNIPAAm layer collapsed and the pores on nanocages 133 were exposed for interior drug release (Yavuz et al., 2009). The state of the art of AuNPs-based 134 chemo-photothermal therapy has been wonderfully summarized in some review articles (Wang et al., 135 2013b; Zhang et al., 2013; Ai et al., 2016; Kim et al., 2016). 136
Despite the tremendous attentions and encouraging results on AuNPs, some important issues should 137 be addressed before further applications. On the one hand, AuNPs are subject to deformation upon 138 high-power laser irradiation, leading to loss of LSPR absorption in the NIR region (Opletal et al., 139 2011; Young et al., 2012). On the other hand, the in vivo long-term toxicity and clearance pathways 140 of AuNPs are still uncertain and require further study. To date, some studies have unveiled potential 141 factors that have effect on AuNPs cytotoxicity. It is believed that surface charge and particle size are 142 likely to be the most influential factors. It was reported that half the dose of positively charged 5 nm 143 AuNPs were excreted after 5 days, while only about 10% of the dose of negatively or neutrally 144 charged 5 nm particles were excreted (Balogh et al., 2007). Most of AuNPs accumulations occur 145 within liver and spleen after intravenous injection of PEG-coated AuNRs (Glenn et al., 2010). 146 Moreover, chronic inflammation was observed in tissues around these AuNPs, despite the unclear 147 long-term consequence under this type of chronic inflammation. In vivo observation of AuNPs only 148 take place up to six months in animal models, leaving unanswered questions about the potential 149 influence on health over long time course. 150
3.2 Palladium nanosheets and copper chalcogenides nanocrystals 151
Another noble metal-based nanostructure, Pd nanosheets, has also been developed to conduct chemo-152 photothermal therapy. Pd nanosheets exhibit tunable LSPR peaks in the NIR region, as well as 153 photothermal stability, thermal transformation efficiency and biocompatibility (Huang et al., 2011). 154 To facilitate the hyperthermia-assisted chemotherapy, Pd nanosheets were deposited onto hollow 155 mesoporous silica particles or coated with a mesoporous silica layer to achieve drug release under 156 NIR irradiation and low pH (Fang et al., 2012a; Fang et al., 2012b). Besides noble metal-based 157 nanomaterials, copper chalcogenides nanocrystals have been supposed to be a promising 158 photothermal agent in biomedical applications. Being p-type semiconductors, copper chalcogenides 159 nanocrystals provide composition-dependent LSPR in NIR region and high photothermal conversion 160 efficiency (Hessel et al., 2011; Lie et al., 2014). Kumar et al. decorated Cu2S nanocrystals with 161 polyethylene glycol (PEG) and folate (PEG-Fol-Cu2S) to physically absorb doxorubicin (DOX) for 162 multimodal therapeutics against brain cancer cells (Poulose et al., 2015). The folate targeted 163 photothermal ablation in synergism with photo-responsive DOX release proved to be a rapid 164 precision guided cancer-killing module (Figure 2A). Hu et al. reported a low-toxic di-functional 165 nanoplatform based on Cu2-xSe@mSiO2-PEG core-shell nanoparticles for cancer treatment (Liu et al., 166 2014). DOX was loaded into mesoporous silica shell, and the release of DOX can be triggered by pH 167 and NIR laser, resulting in a synergistic effect in anti-tumor therapy. The chemo-photothermal 168 therapy driven by NIR radiation with safe power density significantly improved the therapeutic 169 efficacy (Figure 2B). In another work, DOX loaded PEG-Cu2-xTe nanocubes were developed for 170

3.3 Two-dimensional transition metal dichalcogenides 174
In recent years, a class of two-dimensional transition metal dichalcogenides (2D TMDCs) has 175 attracted tremendous attention. 2D TMDCs are typically made up of a layer of transition metal 176 atomssandwiched between two layers of chalcogen atoms. Their generalized formula is MX2, where 177 M is a transition metal of groups 4-10 (Mo, W, Ti, Ta, Zr, V, Nb, etc.) and X is a chalcogen 178 (Chhowalla et al., 2013). Single-layered 2D TMDCs exhibit superior properties, such as strong NIR 179 absorbance, high photothermal conversion efficiency as well as good photothermal stability, offering 180 the possibility to be excellent photothermal agents (Wang et al., 2016a; Zhu et al., 2017). Moreover, 181 the ultra-high surface area of 2D TMDCs endows themselves with efficient cargo loading ability as 182 drug carriers for chemotherapy. 183
Meng et al. prepared aptamer conjugated PEG-MoS2/Cu1.8S nanosheets (ATPMC) as multifunctional 184 platforms for chemo-photothermal therapy (Meng et al., 2017). ATPMC nanoplatform possessed 185 superb photothermal conversion efficiency due to the interactions of MoS2/Cu1.8S nanocomposites. 186 DOX loaded ATPMC displayed NIR laser-induced programmed chemotherapy and advanced 187 photothermal therapy, and the targeted chemo-photothermal therapy presented excellent antitumor 188 efficiency (Figure 3A). In another work, flower-like MoS2 nanoparticles coated with bovine serum 189 albumin (BSA) were successfully fabricated to load DOX for cancer treatment (Chen et al., 2016a). 190 Fabricated MoS2@BSA-DOX exhibited high photothermal conversion efficiency as well as 191 intelligent drug release. Combination of DOX release and photothermal treatment displayed better 192 therapeutic efficacy than single photothermal therapy or chemotherapy (Figure 3B). Kim et al. 193 reported a photothermally controllable DOX-MoS2@SiO2-PEG nanoplate as functional drug delivery 194 carrier (Lee et al., 2016). DOX release was facilitated by external NIR laser irradiation under acidic 195 pH. Enhanced anticancer effect of DOX-MoS2@SiO2-PEG was achieved by the combination of heat 196 damage and enhanced DOX release as well as endosomal escape (Figure 3C). 197
Beside MoS2 nanosheetes, other 2D TMDCs have also been studied for the application of chemo-198 photothermal therapy (Wang et al., 2019b). Jiang et al. successfully prepared MoSe2@PDA-DOX to 199 be applicable for multi-modal chemo-photothermal therapy (Wang et al., 2016a). MoSe2@PDA-200 DOX nanocomposites showed high loading efficiency and NIR-responsive DOX release. Synergistic 201 therapy significantly inhibited cancer cell viability, and suppressed in vivo tumor growth (Figure 3D). 202 In addition, Liu et al. fabricated WS2nanosheets with iron oxide (IO) nanoparticles on surface, 203 subsequently coated with mesoporous silica shell and PEG (Yang et al., 2015a). The obtained WS2-204 IO@MS-PEG nanocomposites exhibited high NIR light and X-ray absorbance as well as NIR-205 responsive DOX release. Chemo-photothermal therapy based on WS2-IO@MS-PEG/DOX achieved 206 a remarkable synergistic effect superior to the respective mono-therapies (Figure 3E). 207
As other metal nanomaterials, biosafety is one of the most concerning issues for 2D TMDCs in 208 biomedical applications, while the knowledge about toxicity for 2D TMDCs is very limited. Till now, 209 only a few 2D TMDCs have been tested for their in vitro and in vivo cytotoxicity, and further studies 210 should be systematically carried out to examine their acute and long-term cytotoxicity. 211

Over the past few decades, a range of carbon nanoallotropes with surprising properties and diverse 213 potential applications have been discovered, such as carbon nanotubes (Iijima, 1991), graphene 214 (Novoselov et al., 2004), carbon dots (Xu et al., 2004), fullerene (Kroto et al., 1985) and 215 nanodiamonds (Niwase et al., 1995). The majority of the interest in carbon nanomaterials for 216 biomedical applications relates to bio-imaging and cancer treatment because of their extraordinary 217 photon-to-thermal conversion efficiency and ultrahigh surface area (Lim et al., 2014), as well as the 218 ability to integrate different biomolecules and drugs on a nanoscale platform, generating advanced 219 hybrid delivery systems. 220
4.1 Graphene/Graphene oxide 221
Graphene is a two-dimension shaped carbon nanoallotrope, in which carbon atoms are arranged in a 222 single atom thick sheet packed into a honeycomb lattice (Novoselov et al., 2004). The unique feature 223 of graphene provide tremendous tunable surface with great mechanical Young’s modulus, fracture 224 strength, electrical, thermal and optical properties (Yang et al., 2010; Feng and Liu, 2011). Graphene 225 oxide (GO) is a highly oxidized form of graphene that is comprised of single atom carbon sheet with 226 carboxylate groups on the border areas, and hydroxyl, epoxide groups on the basal surface. 227 Carboxylate groups provide negatively charged surface and colloidal stability, whereas basal planes 228 offer π-π interaction for the absorption of drug molecules. Like other nanomaterials-based 229 photothermal agents, PEGylated GO and reduced GO exhibit high NIR absorbance and capacity in 230 photothermal treatment (Robinson et al., 2011; Yang et al., 2012a; Zaharie-Butucel et al., 2019). 231 Meanwhile, due to the ultrahigh surface area and delocalized π electron, many anticancer agents such 232 as camptothecin (CPT), DOX, and 7-ethyl-10-hydroxycamptothecin (SN38) have been successfully 233 loaded onto the GO surface (Li et al., 2006; Zhang et al., 2010; Bao et al., 2011; Pan et al., 2011). 234 The works concerning on nano-graphene based chemo-photothermal therapy have been well 235 reviewed (Yang et al., 2013; Orecchioni et al., 2015; Rahman et al., 2015; Yang et al., 2015b). For 236 biomedical application of nano-graphene, one of the critical issues is still the potential long-term 237 toxicity in biological systems (Kiew et al., 2016). It is urgent to figure out that whether and how 238 nano-graphene would be gradually degraded in living body, which is essentially unclear at present 239 and needs a lot more efforts in future studies. 240
4.2 Carbon dots and mesoporous carbon nanoparticles 241
Carbon dots (C-dots) are quasi-spherical carbon nanoparticles with diameters of 2-10 nm, and consist 242 of oxygen, nitrogen elements and other doped heteroatoms (Baker and Baker, 2010). Due to their 243 high quantum yield, superior chemical and photostability, low cytotoxicity and low cost, C-dots are 244 generally regarded as a promising candidate in cancer therapeutic applications (Zhao et al., 2015; 245 Zheng et al., 2015; Wang and Qiu, 2016). Gomes et al. prepared PEG2000 passivated nitrogen-doped 246 C-dots (CND-P) to remotely initiate the delivery of DOX in 3D cultured MCF-7 cells (Ardekani et 247 al., 2017). CND-P possessed high drug loading capacity with the ability to release DOX under two-248 photon excitation. CND-P/DOX mediated chemo-photothermal treatment was superior to single 249 treatment of CND-P or DOX in killing efficiency (Figure 4A). Moreover, magnetofluorescent C-dots 250 were also reported as chemo-photothermal therapeutic agents (Zhang et al., 2017a; Zhang et al., 251 2017b). For example, Zhou et al. prepared Gd doped magnetofluorescent C-dots (GdN@CQDs) as 252 drug carriers, followed with cross-linking by genipin to form multifunctional delivery system 253 (GdN@CQDs/GP-DOX) with pH- and NIR-triggered drug release (Zhang et al., 2017a). 254 GdN@CQDs/GP demonstrated strong NIR absorption and high photothermal conversion efficiency. 255 Upon laser irradiation, GdN@CQDs/GP-DOX has the ability to achieve synergistic therapeutic effect 256 (Figure 4B). 257

Recently, mesoporous carbon nanoparticles (MCNs) have received considerable attention in the 258 family of carbon-nanomaterials (Fang et al., 2010). This growing interest stems from their intrinsic 259 properties, such as high surface areas, large pore volumes, and well-defined surface properties, 260 offering significant advantages as drug carrier on the basis of higher loading capacity and biologic 261 inertness without cytotoxicity (Karavasili et al., 2013). Furthermore, MCNs could also be used as 262 NIR-absorbing nanomaterials with high photothermal conversion efficacy (Dong et al., 2016; Wang 263 et al., 2019a). Qu et al. developed hyaluronic acid surface-modified MCNs (MCNs-HA) as 264 nanocarriers for effective dual-triggered synergistic cancer therapy (Zhou et al., 2015). This system 265 was sensitive to both intracellular hyaluronidase-1 and GSH level to release loaded DOX. In 266 combination with photothermal therapy, DOX-MCNs-HA showed effective therapeutic efficiency 267 toward target cells (Figure 4C). In another study, hollow porous carbon nanoparticles with C-dots 268 embedded in carbon shell (FPC-NCs) were fabricated (Wang et al., 2015a). Such prepared FPC-NCs 269 demonstrated great potential to combine multiple functions for simultaneous two-photon cell imaging, 270 responsive drug delivery, and photothermal therapy. DOX-loaded FPC-NCs manifested NIR-271 responsive drug release and combined chemo-photothermal therapy (Figure 4D). 272
5 Organic nanomaterials-based chemo-photothermal therapy 273
In spite of the excellent photothermal conversion efficiency, the poor biodegradability and potential 274 long-term toxicity of inorganic nanoparticles are still major obstacles for their clinical applications in 275 the future (Jung et al., 2018). In this regard, organic nanoparticles usually exhibit optimized 276 biodegradability and biocompatibility as an alternative approach for combined chemo-photothermal 277 therapy in cancer treatment (Shi et al., 2017; Pierini et al., 2018). Additionally, organic nanoparticles 278 have other attractive advantages such as facile preparation under mild conditions, desirable 279 photothermal features based on easily tuning molecular structures, and satisfactory drug loading 280 efficiency (Yue et al., 2017). In this section, we will mainly talk about small molecular NIR dyes, 281 conjugated polymers and melanin-like polydopamine based organic nano-systems and their 282 applications in synergistic chemo-photothermal therapy. 283
5.1 Small Molecular NIR Dyes 284
Over the past few years, small molecular NIR dyes have attracted lots of attention mainly due to their 285 excellent performance in fluorescent imaging and the ease of tuning photothermal features through 286 elaborate chemical design and synthesis. In principle, these organic dyes with strong NIR absorbance 287 can serve as photothermal agents as well (Song et al., 2015). Therefore, nano-systems containing 288 NIR dyes can be easily designed as a nano-platform for multifunctional theranostics. To date, the 289 well-studied NIR dyes include porphyrin, cyanine derivatives, borondipyrromethane dyes, 290 diketopyrrolopyrrole derivatives and so on (Cai et al., 2018). Direct use of NIR dyes is mainly 291 hindered by the rapid blood clearance following with undesired aggregation caused by the poor 292 aqueous solubility/stability and nonspecific protein adsorption (Chen et al., 2016c). From this point 293 of view, NIR dyes are similar to many anticancer drugs which usually need to be administrated in the 294 form of nano-formulations to improve therapeutic efficacy. Therefore, rational design of nano-295 systems with drugs/NIR dyes either encapsulated or conjugated is of great significance to achieve 296 favorable synergistic outcomes of chemo-photothermal therapy. 297
The simplest way to combine NIR dyes and chemotherapeutic drugs is co-encapsulation in one 298 nanoparticle by physical interactions. Cai et al. prepared poly(lactic-co-glycolic acid) (PLGA)-299 lecithin-PEG nanoparticles (DINPs) containing both DOX and indocyanine green (ICG) by a single-300 step sonication method (Zheng et al., 2013). The stability of ICG was significantly improved by encapsulation in DINPs, 303 thus generating higher localized temperature than free ICG under NIR laser irradiation and 304 facilitating DOX release and cellular uptake. Encouragingly, combined chemo-photothermal therapy 305 realized successful suppression of MCF-7 and DOX-resistant MCF-7/ADR tumor growth as well as 306 prevention of tumor recurrence in vivo. Similarly, many other attempts have been made to co-307 encapsulate various NIR dyes and drugs in different kinds of nano-carriers like liposomes (Li et al., 308 2015; Feng et al., 2016; Yan et al., 2016; Gao et al., 2018; Mu et al., 2019), polymeric nanoparticles 309 (Su et al., 2015; Zhu et al., 2015; Chen et al., 2017b; Wang et al., 2017; Deng et al., 2018; He et al., 310 2018a; Yao et al., 2018; Tan et al., 2019; Zhang et al., 2019), protein nanoparticles (Chen et al., 2015; 311 Lin and Shieh, 2018; Gao et al., 2019; Pei et al., 2019) and cell membranes (Sun et al., 2015; Li et al., 312 2018c; Wan et al., 2018; Zhang et al., 2018b; Ye et al., 2019). For example, Liu et al. developed 313 “Abraxane-like” nanodrug through self-assembly of human serum albumin (HSA), paclitaxel (PTX), 314 and ICG in a simple mixing manner (Chen et al., 2015). The nanodrug remarkably improved 315 solubility of both PTX and ICG, achieving prolonged blood circulation time and high tumor 316 accumulation. The combined chemo-photothermal therapy completely destructed subcutaneous 317 tumors and exhibited great therapeutic benefit in treating lung metastasis. The excellent therapeutic 318 effect and FDA-approved components endow this “Abraxane-like” nanodrug with great potential for 319 clinical use in the future. 320
The simple processing method of physically co-encapsulated nano-formulations is usually preferred 321 for clinical translation. However, undesirable premature leakage of drugs and NIR dyes during 322 administration can happen and lead to insufficient tumor accumulation and potential adverse effects 323 as well. Covalent conjugation of drugs and/or NIR dyes to nano-carriers is believed to potently 324 address this issue. Polymeric prodrugs with therapeutic molecules reversibly linked to polymer 325 chains have already been extensively studied for their longer blood circulation time, higher tumor 326 accumulation and better therapeutic effect but lower systemic toxicity (Duncan, 2006; Larson and 327 Ghandehari, 2012; Delplace et al., 2014). Therefore, polymeric prodrug assemblies can serve as a 328 good platform for co-loading of NIR dyes to perform combinedchemo-photothermal therapy. 6 Conclusion and Outlook 508
In this review, we summarized recent advances in NIR light responsive nanomaterials for combined 509 chemo-photothermal cancer therapy. Metal-, carbon-based and organic nanomaterials were included 510 to discuss their design, preparation and application in combined therapy for improving cancer 511 treatment. The combined chemo-photothermal therapy has been widely evaluated to show synergistic 512 anticancer effect in a ‘1+1>2’ manner. On the one hand, hyperthermia induced by photothermal 513 agents upon specific NIR laser irradiation in the tumor region can not only kill cancer cells directly, 514 but also serve as heat trigger to stimulate drug release in a controlled manner and facilitate cell 515 membrane permeability to enhance drug uptake. On the other hand, optimized chemotherapy by 516 systematic administration of anticancer drugs can help to completely eradicate tumors together with 517 photothermal therapy. The combined chemo-photothermal therapy has also shown excellent 518 performance in overcoming MDR and lung metastasis. 519
In spite of the rapid development and promising potential of nanomaterials for chemo-photothermal 520 therapy, there still exist several critical issues that need to be addressed. Firstly, the photothermal 521 conversion efficiency, which will significantly influence the dosage of photothermal agents and NIR 522 light intensity/irradiation time for efficient heat generation, differs among various nanomaterials 523 concerned in this review. Photothermal conversion efficiencies of several kinds of nanomaterials are 524 summarized in Table 1. More efforts are needed to be put into the creation of novel nanomaterials 525 with favorable photothermal conversion efficiency in order to achieve satisfactory photothermal 526 outcome and reduce the administration dose of nanomaterials. Secondly, though NIR laser can reach 527 deeper tumor tissues, the penetrated depth is still limited. Therefore, the non-invasive photothermal 528 therapy seems mostly feasible for superficial tumors. For internal organ tumors, efficient 529

Lastly, the mechanism of synergistic effect for 542 combined chemo-photothermal therapy needs deeper investigation in the future. Hyperthermia has 543 been reported to increase vascular permeability within tumor tissues, thus promoting drug enrichment 544 and enhancing therapeutic outcome of chemotherapy. Photothermal therapy has been 546 proved to significantly reduce drug efflux by inhibiting P-glycoprotein expression with augmentation 547 of drug sensitivity to cancer cells. Regardless of the existing challenges, chemo-photothermal combination therapy has shown 553 promising results in many experiments. With the rapid development of nanoscience, material 554 chemistry, and tumor biology, we believe that successful clinical applications of nanomaterials for 555 chemo-photothermal cancer treatment can be expected in the future. 556
